body.head: Perth
body.p: When Ruskin began visiting his Aunt Jessie and his cousins as a boy in the 1820s, Perth boasted monuments of the Scottish Enlightenment. Most notable was the new bridge (1771). . .

A visit to his aunt and cousins presented Ruskin with a constant reminder of those Enlightenment monuments, as his relatives lived in Bridge End House, its name taken from its situation near the river, close to where the new bridge met the bank opposite the city. Now destroyed, it was a two-story, stone dwelling, with a basement and attic. See Van Akin Burd's description of the house and purchase details, and his photograph of the river view taken from the upper story (Ruskin Family Letters, 101 n. 2, and pl. 9).
Beattie: "one of the first places in Scotland where Knox promulgated the doctrines of the Reformation,--which here took strong hold of the public mind" (2:21)
